comments.text:
WARNING: Welding galvanized metals can release toxic zinc-oxide fumes. 
Proper eye protection and ventilation are recommended. I run the system on 
240 VAC, which is metered by a power controller I built called the 
"Scariac". It's similar to the idea of a Variac (variable auto-controller), 
with a few more hazards to be aware of. The Micro-Welder itself does not 
have an on-off switch, and can pose a fire hazard if plugged directly into 
a mains power socket. I made this to be used exclusively with the Scariac. 
(Look for how to build that in another project.) Stick welding, and/or the 
modification of a Microwave Oven Transformer (M.O.T), can be very dangerous 
and presents risk of UV radiation, shock hazards, burns, fires, fumes and a 
multitude of other risks. This project should not be attempted without 
adult supervision and adequate training. Misuse, or careless use, of tools 
or projects may result in serious injury. Use of this video content is at 
your own risk.

In the Description!

comments.text:
I am an AWS certified welder, spent the last 2 years training and learning 
about welding. I'm only 19, but I went to a tech school that welding 
program operates on a college curiculum and we are the best high school 
welding program in the state. It isn't the best thing to weld galvanized, 
but as long as you take proper precautions you'll be okay. Also make sure 
you wear some sort of respirator or dust mask. It'll help keep any fumes 
that didn't get exhausted out of your lungs.
comments.author: Tyler Purhamus

comments.text:
Ah ok thank you for clearing that up. Im currently working on an AS degree 
with welding as a major. My professor stressed to never ever ever ever weld 
on galvanized unless if you ground off the zinc oxide coating first.
comments.author: Gofeball Mcsullivan

comments.text:
I've welded galvanized before. As long as you have proper ventilation and 
don't lean directly into the smoke coming off the weld you'll be fine. and 
by proper ventilation I mean an exhaust fan directly above the metal 
pulling fumes away from you.

comments.author: sam badcock

comments.text:
You can weld with your bare hands if you like... The arc will follow the 
least resistive path which is the metal.
comments.author: Alex Chulzhanov

comments.text:
That's.... unlikely. The voltage at the tip is only about 1V, it can't jump 
across to your hand. It's not like a high voltage arc - it can only flow 
directly through the plasma at the tip of the rod created by the high 
temperature. The bigger danger is getting splashes of molten steel on your 
hand, which isn't very nice.
comments.author: GRAHAMAUS

top_comment.author: TDN

comments.text:
+Jesus C The shade depends of the amperage used, that depends of the method 
of welding you're using.
In that case (SMAW), Fewer than 60A is a shade of 7.
60-160A is a shade of 8.
More than 160-250 is a shade of 10.
More than 250-550 is a shade of 11.
(source: 
https://www.osha.gov/Publications/OSHAfactsheet-eyeprotection-during-welding.pdf
)
And personally, for plasma cutter, I prefer to use a shade higher than 5 
(like 8) because it looks like my eyes are more sensitive!
comments.author: InvisibleSparta

comments.text:
+InvisibleSparta Added note: as well covering your face when chipping off 
slag is recommended...... Unless you want hot metal searing your skin...  

10 shade is recommended for stick welding, that is around a 5 shade, which 
is just used for cutting. Like with the oxyfuel torch or plasma cutter.
comments.author: norman ee (normanee)

comments.text:
Few things I noticed being not totally safe in this video:

-Protective gear for the face (this man can suffer a sunburn like on his 
face because he's not wearing a full face!)

-Proper ventilation for the welding smokes (galvanized steel makes toxic 
smoke!!)

And lastly, the welding machine was homemade and might not respect 
electrical and heating rules of safety!
Otherwise, if you know what you're doing like FullFledged2010 said, you'll 
probably weld tons of fun things without any issues :)

trading the TV for an SSD I am currently using. not bad for a dumpster find

captions.text: I found this microwave in my neighbors garbage can. So I took it home, and turned into an

AC stick welder. In this project, we'll be
testing out this contraption to see if it

actually works. Because if it does, we'll
have the metal welding power to make a puzzle

for entertaining guests, or build improvised
weapons for a zombie apocalypse.

I just modified these microwave oven transformers
to weld metal, and made a little container

for it all to fit into. This arc welder is
finished and ready for testing, so to do that

I got some pieces of scrap metal from a welding
shop down the road. I switched out the blade

on my chop-saw with this cutting wheel and
I'm cutting these bits of steel into smaller

pieces. The sparks are pretty hot and fly
everywhere, so it's important to wear protection

and keep them away from anything flammable.
Ok, our pieces are cut and resting on this

larger piece of metal. This is gonna act
as a base plate for the ground clip to connect

to. I've got a 6013 welding rod that gets
clipped into the stinger, and the amperage

is controlled with this device I call the
ScariAc. Look for how to build this in another

video. The amps are adjusted to work with
these 1/16" cellulose coated rods, and with

2 of our pieces butted up next to each other,
it's time to see if we can strike an arc.

They say it's kind of like striking a match,
and there we go. These welding rods are consumable,

meaning they get used up in the weld. You
can actually see where the end of the rod

turns to molten metal and pools into the joint.
To give this a little more strength,

let's flip it over and do the same thing to
the top side. The UV radiation from stick

welding is enough to give you a pretty bad
sun burn, so if you try it, make sure you're

protected from head to toe. Alright, the weld
has cooled, so now we can knock off the layer

of slag that's formed on top, then clean it
up with a wire brush. Now it looks good to

me, but I've never really welded before so
I'm not sure how to tell if the weld is good

or not, so let's break it. The piece gets
clamped in a bench vise and these channel

lock pliers should give us the leverage we
need. I'm actually expecting this will snap

in the middle … but it didn't. I welded
another piece and tried bending it back and

forth multiple times to snap the weld, but
the joint never broke. Just for fun and a

bit more practice, let's weld all the scrap
pieces together. I've also got these framing

nails we can tack on in random places, and
a link of galvanized chain we can weld to

the end. Well, I think it's safe to say this
welder is working. And I've got my first piece

of metal art to prove it. It's a little rough,
and probably not the kind of decor I'd want

to put on display, but in a weird way I kind
of like it. Now I'm amazed that even with

all this welding, the transformer coils are
only slightly warm to the touch. I tried welding

some larger 3/32 rods and that was a different
story. They work alright, but the welder heats

up fast. To cool it down, I have a fan that
was salvaged from one of the microwaves, and

it slides right up to the vent hole on the
left. When it's turned on, air flows over

the transformer coils, and exhausts out the
other side. In the case of extreme overheating,

the whole top lifts right off for maximum
ventilation. This welds metal pretty good

in my opinion, but I took it to another welder
to get his thoughts on how it worked. He tried

some welds on pieces of his own scrap steel,
and seemed pretty impressed with the results.

He said the weld penetrated the metal completely,
and probably wouldn't break. So we tried some

more destructive testing to break the weld,
but even with good leverage and quite a bit

of force, the weld held strong and the metal
broke first. To finish this project up, let's

try making something a little more useful.
This time I've got a horseshoe and some chain,

and I'm welding the links in-line with the
tips of the shoe. This 2" steel ring goes

over both of the chains, and the remaining
links are welded onto another shoe. We can

clean up the welds in the usual way, and look
at that. We've got a horseshoe puzzle ready

for entertaining. The challenge is to get
the ring off, which seems impossible because

the ring is way too small. But it can be done,
and my wife just proved it. Why don't you

make your own and see if you can figure out
how it's done? Well there's a MOT stick welder

that works, and my first few experiences with
the world of welding. If you liked this project,

perhaps you'll like some of my others. Check
them out at www.thekingofrandom.com

title: Homemade Stick Welder - From Microwave Parts!
